授業目的: Diversity and inclusion are two interconnected concepts and sets of principles that are seen as very important today in a number of fields, but especially education, health and employment. While diversity and inclusion are often used as a set phrase, they are not interchangeable. Diversity as a concept and principle refers to the (equal) representation of people in all their variety – gender and gender identity, religious background, economic background, race or ethnic background, sexual orientation and even neurological/cognitive traits. Inclusion is about how well the presence, contributions and perspectives of different groups of people are valued and integrated into an environment such as a school or workplace. This course will provide opportunities for students to study and explore in more detail diversity and inclusion as concepts, as well as issues of discrimination and inequality.
到達目標:
By the end of this course it is expected that students will:
1) Have a solid understanding of the concepts of diversity and inclusion;
2) To be able to discuss and offer informed opinion on a number of diversity and inclusion issues;
3) To offer advice on how to set and achieve diversity and inclusion goals
4) To gain confidence in having meaningful conversations about difference;
5) Understand the some of the challenges of moving from principles to practice

本授業科目は、“オンライン授業60単位制限対象科目”ではありません。
The course is not subject to the 60-credit limit for online courses.
授業方法: In this class we will explore the interconnected concepts of diversity and inclusion. We will start by examining these two concepts, their history and the variety of meaning, and their usage. Next, we will explore different sets of diversity and inclusion issues in the contexts of race and ethnicity, ability and disability, gender, sexuality and gender identification, age and ageing, and socioeconomic status. At the same time, we will seek to better understand how those who are different can be marginalized, experience discrimination, unequal power relations and even oppression. The course will also explore the roots of resilience, community, and the generation of social capital that can enrich the lived experiences of and create support structures for those who tend to be marginalized.
